references.text: Since most of the discussion concerning spatial evolution will refer to fields that are laterally confined and thus undergo spreading, we will use "diffraction" to refer to the general problem of propagation. Although we often associate diffraction with wave propagation involving an obstacle such as an edge or an aperture, these objects can be accounted for in the initial field distribution in the Huygens-Fresnel integral and, as such, represent special cases of the general wave propagation problem.

references.text: Given that the element pitch d equals λ0/2 at the center frequency of the transducer, f0 = c/λ0, and that a high-quality saw gives an element gap of d — w = 25μm, then the approximation of (18) biases σb estimates less than 5% (w/d = 1 — 2f0(d — w)/c ≥ 0.7 in Fig. 3) when f0 ≤ 0.3c/2(d — w) ≃ 9 MHz. This frequency range encompasses most of diagnostic imaging. For the 5 MHz linear array used in this study, w/d ≃ 0.83. We estimate from the data in Fig. 3 that the measurements in Figs. 6 and 7 are biased high by only 1%.
